questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a young child who is experiencing mild intermittent upper abdominal pain and has an X-ray shown below?
questions.solution:
A Morgagni hernia is a rare type of diaphragmatic hernia where abdominal contents herniate into the thoracic cavity through the foramen of Morgagni (anterior defect of the diaphragm).

Clinical features: Often presents with mild, intermittent abdominal pain, respiratory symptoms, or may be asymptomatic.

X-ray findings: On a chest X-ray, the herniated bowel loops may appear as air-filled structures in the anterior mediastinum, often on the right side near the heart.

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH):

  1. CDH is the intrathoracic herniation of abdominal contents due to congenital defects in the diaphragm.
  2. Types of CDH:
    • Bochdalek Hernia: Occurs through the posterolateral pleuroperitoneal canal, most commonly on the left side.
    • Morgagni Hernia: Anterior hernia located at the right cardiophrenic angle.

Fig. Schematic representation of CDH

  1. Radiologic Features:
    • Chest Radiograph (CXR):
      • Bochdalek hernia: Dome-shaped soft tissue opacity in the posterolateral thorax, often left-sided.
      • May show gas-filled bowel loops or fat content in the thoracic cavity.
      • Mediastinal shift away from the herniation due to mass effect.
      • On the lateral view, hernias appear above the posterior costophrenic recess.
    • CT/MRI:
      • Visualizes herniation of fat, bowel, spleen, or kidney through a diaphragmatic defect.
      • Important for distinguishing from other masses like cystic adenomatoid malformation or pericardial cyst.
      • CT provides clearer differentiation of soft-tissue or fatty mass protruding through the diaphragm.
  2. Complications:
    • Associated with hypoplasia of the ipsilateral lung, leading to respiratory distress, especially in neonates.
    • Neonates may present with respiratory distress and mediastinal deviation.

 

Bochdalek hernia (option A): Incorrect because a Bochdalek hernia is a posterior diaphragmatic hernia, typically found on the left side. It is more common in neonates and is not located anteriorly.

 

Gastric volvulus (option C): Incorrect because gastric volvulus involves twisting of the stomach, often leading to acute severe pain and vomiting, which does not match the mild, intermittent pain described here. X-ray would show a "double bubble" or distended stomach with air-fluid levels.


Eventration of diaphragm (option D): Incorrect because eventration refers to abnormal elevation of the diaphragm, often involving one hemidiaphragm, but does not involve herniation of bowel loops into the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: The following radiological image was taken to assess the urinary tract. Identify the investigation shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Intravenous pyelogram (IVP)

Explanation:

  • An Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) is a contrast-based radiological investigation used to visualize the anatomy and function of the urinary tract, including kidneys, ureters, and bladder.
  • Iodinated contrast is injected intravenously, filtered by the kidneys, and excreted into the collecting system, allowing sequential imaging to assess drainage and detect structural abnormalities such as calculi, strictures, or masses.
  • The image typically shows contrast-filled calyces, pelvis, ureters, and bladder in a single study.

Incorrect Options:

Pelvic X-ray (Option B): Plain film without contrast; only bony pelvis and gross calcifications visible.

Retrograde pyelogram (Option C): Contrast introduced via catheter through the urethra and bladder directly into ureters; used if IV contrast is contraindicated.

Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG) (Option D): Contrast instilled into bladder via catheter, with imaging during urination; used for vesicoureteral reflux evaluation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with complaints of lower abdominal pain, and passage of blood mixed with stools for the past 3 months. Based on his radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option A) Ulcerative colitis

Explanation

Option A - Ulcerative Colitis (UC) - Symptoms:

  • Lower abdominal pain: Common in UC, often colicky or cramping.
  • Passage of blood mixed with stools: A cardinal symptom of UC, as the inflammation primarily affects the superficial mucosal lining, leading to friability and bleeding.
  • 3 months duration: Fits the chronic, relapsing-remitting nature of IBD.
  • 26-year-old male: UC commonly presents in young adults.

Ulcerative Colitis (UC) - Xrays

  • Loss of haustral markings ("lead pipe" or "garden hose" appearance): This is a classic sign of chronic UC due to continuous inflammation and fibrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pseudomembranous Colitis (PMC) - X-rays:

  • Often non-specific in early or mild cases.
  • Colonic dilatation: Can be diffuse or segmental.
  • Nodular haustral thickening / "Thumbprinting": This is a relatively classic finding, representing prominent edema and thickening of the haustral folds, and is often more pronounced than in UC. It can also be seen in ischemic colitis.

Option C - Crohn's Disease - X-rays:

  • Often normal.
  • Dilated loops of small bowel with air-fluid levels: Suggestive of small bowel obstruction, a common complication due to strictures.
  • "String sign": Severe narrowing of a segment of bowel, often the terminal ileum, appearing as a thin, continuous string of barium. This indicates a stricture.
  • "Skip lesions": Inflamed areas separated by normal bowel, a characteristic feature. Difficult to see on plain X-ray, more apparent on barium studies.

Option D - Intestinal Tuberculosis (TB) - X-rays:

  • Often non-specific.
  • Ascites: Can be present, especially in peritoneal TB.
  • Absence of gas shadows in the right iliac fossa: Due to thickened, matted bowel loops in the ileocecal region.

questions.text: Which of the following images accurately represents the medical condition described in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Diaphragmatic hernia

Explanation:

  • The given chest x-ray shows loops of bowel in the right thoracic cavity, mediastinal shift to the left, and decreased right lung aeration, which is consistent with Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia.

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH):

1. CDH is the intrathoracic herniation of abdominal contents due to congenital defects in the diaphragm.

2. Types of CDH:

  • Bochdalek Hernia: Occurs through the posterolateral pleuroperitoneal canal, most commonly on the left side.
  • Morgagni Hernia: Anterior hernia located at the right cardiophrenic angle.

3. Radiologic Features:

  • Chest Radiograph (CXR):
    • Bochdalek hernia: Dome-shaped soft tissue opacity in the posterolateral thorax, often left-sided.
    • May show gas-filled bowel loops or fat content in the thoracic cavity.
    • Mediastinal shift away from the herniation due to mass effect.
    • On the lateral view, hernias appear above the posterior costophrenic recess.
  • CT/MRI:
    • Visualizes herniation of fat, bowel, spleen, or kidney through a diaphragmatic defect.
    • Important for distinguishing from other masses like cystic adenomatoid malformation or pericardial cyst.
    • CT provides clearer differentiation of soft-tissue or fatty mass protruding through the diaphragm.

4. Complications:

  • Associated with hypoplasia of the ipsilateral lung, leading to respiratory distress, especially in neonates.
  • Neonates may present with respiratory distress and mediastinal deviation.

Incorrect Options:

Intestinal obstruction (Option B):

  • Typically presents with dilated bowel loops confined to the abdominal cavity.
  • Does not involve bowel loops appearing in the chest on imaging.

Pleural effusion (Option C):

  • Characterized by fluid collection in the pleural space.
  • May show blunting of the costophrenic angle or fluid layering but no bowel loops.

Pneumonia (Option D):

  • Presents as patchy or lobar opacities in the lung parenchyma.
  • Does not involve bowel loops in the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The X ray of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intussusception

Explanation:

  • Intussusception is a medical condition in which one segment of the intestine telescopes into another segment, causing an obstruction.
  • In a barium enema procedure (as shown in the image), intussusception may appear as a characteristic ‘claw sign’ appearance, where the affected segment of the intestine invaginates into the adjacent segment. This is due to the filling defect it creates for the enema.

Intussusception

  • Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel is pulled into another, often leading to bowel obstruction and ischemia.
  • It is a common cause of acute abdomen in children, while in adults, it is typically associated with a focal lesion acting as a lead point.
  • The classic clinical presentation of intussusception in children may include intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and a palpable "sausage-like" mass in the right upper quadrant, although these symptoms occur in less than 20% of cases.
  • Parents may also report "currant jelly" stools, indicating bowel ischemia, and approximately 15% of patients may present without abdominal pain.
  • Plain Radiograph:
    • Elongated soft tissue mass in the upper right quadrant.
    • Bowel obstruction with air-fluid levels and proximal bowel dilation.
    • Possible absence of gas in the distal collapsed bowel.
  • Fluoroscopy:
    • Gold standard is the contrast enema, showing the intussusception as an occluding mass.
    • Characteristic "coiled spring sign."

Fig. Coiled spring sign

  • Ultrasound:
    • Target sign (doughnut sign)- Concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechoic bands are observed, where the echogenic bands represent the serosa and submucosa, flanking the hypoechoic muscularis propria.
  • Pseudokidney sign- Longitudinal ultrasound appearance of the intussuscepted segment of bowel which mimics a kidney
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.
  • Absence of blood flow in the intussusceptum (contraindication for enema).
  • Features favoring ileocolic intussusception: hyperechoic core, thicker outer hypoechoic wall, larger anteroposterior diameter, and presence of lymph nodes.
  • CT Scan:
    • Characteristic "bowel-within-bowel" configuration.
    • Concentric rings of bowel on axial images, and sausage-shaped mass on longitudinal images.
    • Visualization of the lead point if present, with surrounding mesenteric fat and vessels.

Volvulus (Option B) refers to the twisting or rotation of a portion of the intestine, leading to obstruction of the blood supply and potential bowel strangulation. In a barium enema, volvulus may appear as a characteristic "bird's beak" or "corkscrew" appearance.

Diverticulitis (Option C) is the inflammation or infection of small pouches called diverticula that can develop in the colon. During a barium enema, diverticulitis may present as localized outpouching or sac-like structures filled with barium. Inflammation and thickening of the bowel wall may be visible, and in severe cases, abscesses or fistulas may be observed.

Ulcerative Colitis (Option D) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the colon and rectum. In a barium enema, ulcerative colitis may show diffuse inflammation and ulceration of the colonic mucosa. The bowel wall may appear thickened, with loss of haustral markings (the characteristic folds of the colon) and a coarse or granular appearance. The extent and severity of the disease can be evaluated using barium enema imaging.

questions.text:
What is the likely diagnosis for a 20-year-old male who presents with pain in the right flank, along with fever and chills?

The patient experiences pain when the hip is passively extended on the right side. Lab tests indicate an increased white blood cell count, and a CT scan reveals specific findings.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Psoas abscess

Explanation:

  • A psoas abscess is the pus collection which is located in the iliopsoas compartment. The classical presentation is back pain, fever, and limping.
  • The pain on passive extension occurs due to muscles causing friction against inflamed tissue. The CT scan demonstrates abnormal fluid collection surrounded by irregular rim enhancement.

Pyelonephritis (Option A) is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidney. It can cause fever and back pain but not limping. The pain will not be present on the passive extension of the hip. CT findings are enlargement of the kidney with thickened parenchyma and an Impairment of corticomedullary differentiation.

Appendicitis (Option C) is an inflammation of the appendix. It causes pain in your lower right abdomen CT findings are dilated appendix with the wall thickening and adjacent mesenteric fat stranding.

Torsion of right undescended testis (Option D) clinical symptoms include nonspecific abdominal pain, poor oral intake, vomiting, and restlessness.CT shows a well-circumscribed, isodense, or hetero-dense mass and had proper fine anatomic detail in locating the undescended testis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intussusception

Explanation:

  • The barium study findings shows barium in the lumen of the intussusception, intramural space, and an occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen, are consistent with intussusception.
  • The description of a "coiled spring appearance" is a classic radiological finding associated with Intussuseption.

Intussusception

  • Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel is pulled into another, often leading to bowel obstruction and ischemia.
  • It is a common cause of acute abdomen in children, while in adults, it is typically associated with a focal lesion acting as a lead point.
  • The classic clinical presentation of intussusception in children may include intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and a palpable "sausage-like" mass in the right upper quadrant, although these symptoms occur in less than 20% of cases.
  • Parents may also report "currant jelly" stools, indicating bowel ischemia, and approximately 15% of patients may present without abdominal pain.
  • Plain Radiograph:
    • Elongated soft tissue mass in the upper right quadrant.
    • Bowel obstruction with air-fluid levels and proximal bowel dilation.
    • Possible absence of gas in the distal collapsed bowel.
  • Fluoroscopy:
    • Gold standard is the contrast enema, showing the intussusception as an occluding mass.
    • Characteristic "coiled spring sign."
  • Ultrasound:
    • Target sign (doughnut sign)- Concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechoic bands are observed, where the echogenic bands represent the serosa and submucosa, flanking the hypoechoic muscularis propria.
    • Pseudokidney sign- Longitudinal ultrasound appearance of the intussuscepted segment of bowel which mimics a kidney
    • Crescent in a doughnut sign.
    • Absence of blood flow in the intussusceptum (contraindication for enema).
    • Features favoring ileocolic intussusception: hyperechoic core, thicker outer hypoechoic wall, larger anteroposterior diameter, and presence of lymph nodes.
  • CT Scan:
    • Characteristic "bowel-within-bowel" configuration.
    • Concentric rings of bowel on axial images, and sausage-shaped mass on longitudinal images.
    • Visualization of the lead point if present, with surrounding mesenteric fat and vessels.

Incorrect Options:  

Volvulus (Option B): This is twisting of a bowel loop, typically causing a "bird beak" or "coffee bean" appearance on imaging, not a coiled spring pattern.

Diverticulitis (Option C): This involves inflammation of diverticula. Imaging may show thickened bowel walls or abscesses but does not produce a coiled spring appearance.

Ulcerative colitis (Option D): This causes continuous inflammation of the colonic mucosa with findings such as lead pipe appearance on barium studies, not a coiled spring pattern.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Carcinoma esophagus

Explanation:

  • The provided barium swallow findings of irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins are highly indicative of carcinoma of the esophagus.
  • It is often associated with symptoms such as dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), weight loss, and loss of appetite.

Radiological findings in Achalasia cardia and Carcinoma Esophagus

Feature

Achalasia Cardia

Carcinoma Esophagus

Esophageal Appearance

Massively dilated esophagus

Irregular narrowing of esophagus

Distal Esophagus

Narrow lower end ("bird beak" sign)

Malignant stricture

Location

Affects lower esophageal sphincter

Mid-esophagus in this case

Contour

Smooth tapering at distal end

Irregular, abrupt narrowing

Additional Features

Proximal esophagus is dilated

May show shouldering or "apple core" appearance (not visible in this image)


Fig. Apple core appearance

Incorrect Options:

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option B): This condition causes a "corkscrew esophagus" or "rosary bead" appearance on barium swallow

Esophageal leiomyoma (Option C): This benign tumor might appear as a smooth, localized filling defect on barium studies

Esophageal web (Option D): Seen in conditions like Plummer-Vinson syndrome, it presents as a thin, membranous structure causing dysphagia.

questions.text: Which of the options below represents a characteristic observed in cases of large bowel obstruction?

choices.text: Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circulars

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dilated loops with haustrations

Explanation:

  • Large bowel obstruction (LBO) typically presents with dilated loops of the colon showing prominent haustra, which are incomplete and widely spaced folds.
  • Unlike small bowel obstruction (SBO), haustral markings do not extend across the entire lumen.

Radiological Features of Bowel Obstruction

Feature

Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)

Large Bowel Obstruction (LBO)

Dilated loops

Central, thin-walled

Peripheral, thick-walled

Folds

Plica circulares (valvulae conniventes)

Haustrations (do not extend completely across the lumen)

"String of pearls" sign

Yes (air-fluid levels in SBO)

String of pearl appearance

 

No

Transition point

Small bowel

Colon or rectosigmoid region

Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circularis (Option A): Incorrect because plicae circulares are characteristic of small bowel obstruction (SBO), not LBO.

String of pearls sign (Option C): Incorrect because this is seen in small bowel obstruction, representing multiple small gas bubbles trapped in fluid-filled loops.

Central dilated bowel loops (Option D): Incorrect because small bowel obstructions usually present with centrally dilated loops, whereas large bowel obstructions show peripheral dilation.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An X-ray was taken which showed dilated bowel loops as given in the image below. Identify the segment involved.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Jejunum

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and the X-ray findings of dilated bowel loops with visible valvulae conniventes suggest small bowel obstruction involving the jejunum.
  • Valvulae conniventes (or plicae circulares):
    • These are mucosal folds that run transversely across the lumen of the jejunum and proximal ileum.
    • They are most prominent in the jejunum and appear as complete lines spanning the width of the bowel on X-ray.

Investigations for Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Initial Diagnostic Test: Abdominal X-ray
    • Erect View:
      • Better for identifying air-fluid levels.
      • Shows dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels in a step-ladder pattern.
  • Supine View:
    • Better for identifying the site of obstruction.
    • Obstruction typically visible in the ileum.
  • IOC-CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):
    • Used for:
      • High-grade obstruction.
      • Extraluminal causes of obstruction.
      • Strangulation.

Radiographic Features

Jejunum

Plicae circulares or valvulae conniventes

  • Visible as circumferential, ring-like patterns.
  • Multiple dilated bowel loops.
  • Loops are centrally located.
  • The mucosal pattern appears well-defined with a “feathery” appearance due to the plicae circulares.

Ileum

(Option B)

Dilated bowel loops.

  • Loops are centrally located.
  • Featureless or “characteristically characterless” appearance, lacking the pronounced mucosal pattern seen in the jejunum.

Duodenum (Option C): Retroperitoneal, less frequently visible on abdominal X-ray unless there is significant dilation.

Transverse colon (Option D): Haustrations (incomplete lines that do not span the full width of the bowel).

questions.text:
A patient following a skid resulting in a motor traffic accident was brought to the emergency room 2 hours later. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechiae were seen. Severe tenderness was elicited in the left hypochondriac region and BP-90/50 mm of Hg. What is the best investigation used in the ER?

GCS: Glasgow coma scale

FAST: Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) FAST

Explanation:

  • In the given scenario, the best investigation to be used in the emergency room is FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).
  • FAST is a rapid bedside ultrasound examination that is commonly used in the emergency setting to evaluate patients with suspected abdominal or thoracic trauma.
  • It is a non-invasive and relatively quick procedure that can provide valuable information about potential injuries and guide further management.

FAST (Focused Abdominal Sonography for Trauma) and eFAST (Extended FAST):

  • Purpose: Assess for free fluid in the abdominal cavity, thoracic cavities, and pericardium.
  • Nature of Injury: Not used to determine the specific nature or extent of injury.
  • Advantages:
    • Rapid, reproducible, portable, and non-invasive bedside test.
    • Can be performed simultaneously with resuscitation.
    • Accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood.
  • Limitations:
    • Operator-dependent and may be unreliable in obese patients or when the bowel is full of gas.
    • Low sensitivity (29–35%) for detecting hollow viscus or solid organ injuries without haemoperitoneum.
    • Unreliable for excluding injuries in penetrating trauma.
    • Requires repeat or supplementary investigations if needed.
    • Unreliable for assessing retroperitoneum.

Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage (DPL): (Option C)

  • Purpose: Assess for the presence of blood or contaminants in the abdomen, valuable in resource-limited settings.
  • Procedure:
    • Nasogastric tube and urinary catheter placement.
    • Cannula insertion below the umbilicus for aspiration and fluid infusion.
    • The positive result is if
      • Frank blood or contaminants are present, or
      • If laboratory results show >100,000 red cells/µL or >500 white cells/µL or
      • Amylase levels in the fluid of more than 175 IU/dl.
    • Drainage of lavage fluid via a chest drain indicates diaphragm penetration.
  • Limitations: Largely replaced by eFAST but remains the standard in some settings where eFAST is unavailable or unreliable.
  • Contraindications:
    • When laparotomy is indicated
    • Previous laparotomy
    • Pregnancy
    • Obesity

X-ray (Option B): are less sensitive in detecting injuries to internal organs. Therefore, it may not be the best initial investigation for this patient.

CT scan (Option B): Gold standard for detailed assessment but requires a stable patient. This patient is hypotensive, making CT less ideal initially.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of dysphagia, which is more pronounced for liquids than solids. Which radiological sign is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rat-tail sign

Explanation:

 

  • Dysphagia that is more pronounced for liquids than solids suggests achalasia, a motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • Achalasia is characterized by failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax, leading to progressive dilation of the esophagus with tapering at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • On barium swallow, achalasia classically shows a "Rat-tail sign"—a smooth, gradual narrowing at the distal esophagus due to the non-relaxing LES.

  • Radiological Signs in Esophageal Disorders

    Radiological Sign

    Associated Condition

    Appearance

    Rat-tail sign (Correct Answer)

    Achalasia

    Smooth tapering of the esophagus at the LES

    Filling defect

    Esophageal tumors, strictures

    Irregular defect in the barium column

    Corkscrew esophagus

    Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)

    Multiple non-peristaltic contractions creating a "corkscrew" pattern

    Apple-core lesion

    Esophageal or colonic cancer

    Constricted lumen with irregular edges, resembling an apple core
     

    Filling defect (Option B) is incorrect because a filling defect is a non-specific radiological finding seen in conditions like oesophageal tumours, varices, or strictures. It does not typically present with dysphagia that is worse for liquids.

     

    Corkscrew oesophagus (Option C) is incorrect because it is seen in diffuse oesophageal spasm (DES), which presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia for both solids and liquids, rather than a progressive pattern.


    Apple-core lesion (Option D) is incorrect because it is a characteristic finding in colorectal cancer, not an oesophageal disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with vague abdominal pain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Angiomyolipoma is a benign renal tumour composed of fat, blood vessels, and smooth muscle. On CT, it is characterised by fat density (-10 to -100 Hounsfield units) within the lesion, which is a hallmark feature.

 

It is most commonly seen in middle-aged individuals and is associated with tuberous sclerosis in some cases.

Angiomyolipoma in both kidneys (arrows) in computer tomography. The tumours are hypodense (dark) due to fat content.

 

RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma) (option A): RCC typically presents as an enhancing mass on CT without significant fat density. It may show irregular enhancement due to necrosis but does not have fat as a primary feature.

 

Renal Oncocytoma (option B): Renal oncocytoma is a benign tumour and appears as a homogeneously enhancing mass on CT but does not exhibit fat density.

 

Renal Cyst (option D): Renal cysts appear as well-defined, non-enhancing lesions with water density (0-20 Hounsfield units) on CT, without fat.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An x-ray was taken which showed dilated bowel loops as given in the image below. Identify the segment involved.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Jejunum

Explanation:

  • The x-ray shows dilated bowel loops with valvulae conniventes (plicae circulares), which are seen throughout the lumen, indicating jejunal obstruction. These folds are closely spaced and extend across the entire diameter of the bowel, a hallmark feature of the jejunum on imaging.

 

Radiological Features of Bowel Obstruction

Segment

Radiological Features

Jejunum

Valvulae conniventes (plicae circulares) seen throughout the bowel, giving a stacked coin or coiled spring appearance.

Ileum

Less prominent valvulae conniventes, fewer folds, and a featureless appearance compared to the jejunum.

Duodenum

Dilated duodenum in proximal obstruction, "double bubble" sign in duodenal atresia.

Transverse Colon

Haustral markings (do not completely cross the lumen), wider spacing than jejunal folds.

 

Differentiating Features Between Small Bowel and Large Bowel Obstruction:

Feature

Small Bowel

Large Bowel

Number of loops

Many loops visible

Few loops visible

Position of loops

Central abdomen

Peripheral (framing the small bowel)

Wall/Mucosal pattern

Valvulae conniventes (complete circular folds)

Haustra (incomplete bands)

Diameter

>3 cm

>6 cm (Caecum >9 cm)

Gas Pattern

Multiple air-fluid levels, "string of beads"

Distended colon, air-fluid levels

 

 

Ileum (Option B): Incorrect because ileal loops have fewer mucosal folds (valvulae conniventes are less prominent), and the dilatation does not show the characteristic stacked-coin appearance of the jejunum.

Duodenum (Option C): Incorrect because duodenal obstruction typically shows a "double bubble" sign in congenital cases or proximal dilatation with stomach involvement.

Transverse Colon (Option D): Incorrect because haustral markings do not completely cross the lumen and are more widely spaced, unlike valvulae conniventes of the jejunum.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below which is the investigation of choice in distal bowel tumors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Barium enema

Explanation:

  • Barium enema is the investigation of choice for distal bowel tumors as it provides a detailed view of the colon and rectum by instilling barium contrast via the rectum. It helps detect colorectal masses, strictures, and mucosal irregularities, making it ideal for evaluating distal bowel pathology.

Barium Studies in Gastrointestinal Imaging

Investigation

Indication

Best for

Barium Swallow

Oropharyngeal and esophageal disorders

Esophageal stricture, achalasia, tumors

Barium Meal

Upper GI tract evaluation (stomach, duodenum)

Peptic ulcer disease, gastric tumors

Barium Meal Follow-through

Small bowel imaging

Crohn’s disease, malabsorption syndromes

Enteroclysis

Detailed small bowel study

Subtle small bowel lesions

Barium Enema

Colon and rectal pathology

Distal bowel tumors, polyps, IBD

 

Enteroclysis (Option A): Incorrect because it is used for small bowel evaluation, not for distal bowel tumors. It requires nasojejunal intubation and is ideal for conditions like Crohn’s disease or malabsorption syndromes.

Barium Meal (Option B): Incorrect because it mainly assesses the stomach and duodenum and is not used for detecting distal colon tumors.

Barium Meal Follow-through (Option C): Incorrect because it is designed for small bowel evaluation and is used for conditions like submucosal tumors or Crohn’s disease, rather than distal colon tumors.

questions.text: Identify the condition depicted in the radiograph below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pancreatic calcification:

  • The radiograph shows small, scattered calcifications typically associated with chronic pancreatitis. These calcifications are due to long-term inflammation and damage to the pancreas, leading to the deposition of calcium within the pancreatic ducts.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not seen in the given radiograph.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary use of this imaging modality?
questions.solution:
• Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a high-resolution imaging modality that combines endoscopy with ultrasonography to provide detailed images of the gastrointestinal (GI) wall and adjacent structures.
  • It is primarily used for staging esophageal cancer, allowing assessment of:
    • Depth of tumor invasion (T stage)
    • Involvement of regional lymph nodes (N stage)
    • Adjacent mediastinal structures
  • EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) can help in obtaining tissue samples from suspicious lymph nodes for accurate staging.

 

 

 

Applications of Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS)

Application

Primary Use

Staging of esophageal cancer (Correct Answer)

Evaluates tumor depth and lymph node involvement

Pancreatic lesions

Detects and biopsies pancreatic cysts, tumors, or chronic pancreatitis

Subepithelial GI tumors

Differentiates between leiomyomas, GISTs, and neuroendocrine tumors

Biliary pathology

Detects choledocholithiasis and bile duct strictures

Rectal cancer staging

Determines depth of invasion and lymph node involvement

Evaluation of GERD (Option B): Incorrect because GERD is typically assessed with pH monitoring, manometry, or upper endoscopy, not EUS.

Identifying the cause of dysphagia (Option C): Incorrect because barium swallow or esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) are first-line tests; EUS is used mainly for cancer staging or assessing submucosal lesions.

Assessing cardiac and aortic pathology (Option D): Incorrect because transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), not EUS, is preferred for cardiac/aortic evaluation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with absolute constipation and abdominal distension. And the X-ray abdomen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• X-ray shows a characteristic "coffee bean sign"- a large, dilated loop of bowel with an inverted U-shape, which is highly suggestive of sigmoid volvulus.
  • Clinical presentation of absolute constipation and abdominal distension is typical of large bowel obstruction.
  • Sigmoid volvulus is common in elderly patients, especially those with chronic constipation, neurological disorders, or bed-ridden status.
  • The transition point is usually at the sigmoid colon, without gas in the rectum.

Sigmoid Volvulus

Feature

Sigmoid Volvulus

Etiology

Chronic constipation, long redundant sigmoid colon

Radiological Sign

Coffee bean sign on X-ray, bird’s beak sign on contrast enema

Symptoms

Abdominal distension, pain, absolute constipation, vomiting

Treatment

Endoscopic detorsion (if no gangrene), surgery for recurrent cases

 

Caecal Volvulus (Option A): Incorrect because caecal volvulus shows a kidney-shaped distended caecum displaced to the upper abdomen, often with small bowel dilatation.

Intestinal Obstruction (Option C): Incorrect because intestinal obstruction is a broad term that includes various causes, whereas the X-ray here is specific for sigmoid volvulus.

Small Bowel Volvulus (Option D): Incorrect because small bowel volvulus presents with central dilated loops with air-fluid levels rather than the classical coffee bean sign.

questions.text: A 6-week-old child is brought to the emergency department with recurrent projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Based on the radiograph provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis:

  • The given radiograph shows an elongated and thickened pylorus, and the clinical presentation suggests congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Annular pancreas: The annular pancreas will present with non-bilious vomiting and is associated with Down's syndrome and Duodenal atresia, but the radiograph is suggestive of CHPS.

Option C - Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia will present with bilious vomiting and show a double bubble sign.

Option D - Meckel’s diverticulum: In Meckel’s diverticulum, the most common presentation is bleeding, not vomiting.

questions.text: The characteristic appearance of the esophagus on barium swallow, as shown in the image below, is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diffuse oesophageal spasm

Explanation:

  • The barium swallow image in diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) classically shows a "corkscrew" or "rosary bead" appearance due to uncoordinated, simultaneous esophageal contractions. This condition presents with intermittent dysphagia and chest pain, often mimicking cardiac conditions.

Radiological Features of Esophageal Conditions

Condition

Barium Swallow Appearance

Key Features

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)

Corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus

Uncoordinated contractions, chest pain, intermittent dysphagia

Esophageal carcinoma

Irregular filling defect, apple-core lesion

Progressive dysphagia, weight loss

Esophageal ulcer

Niche or crater-like defect

Associated with reflux or malignancy

Achalasia cardia

Bird’s beak appearance

Failure of LES relaxation, progressive dysphagia

 

Esophageal carcinoma (Option B): Incorrect because it shows an irregular filling defect or apple-core lesion, not a corkscrew pattern.

Esophageal ulcer (Option C): Incorrect because it presents as a localized crater-like defect in the esophagus, unlike diffuse spasm.

Achalasia cardia (Option D): Incorrect because it shows a bird’s beak appearance due to failure of lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation.

questions.text: What investigation is being performed in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Barium swallow:

  • The given image sequence shows barium swallow.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Fluoroscopy: Fluoroscopy is depicted in a video or movie form.

Options C and D are not depicted in the image.

questions.text: Identify pancreas, liver, and spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-liver, B-pancreas, C-spleen

Explanation:

  • In the given radiological image, the stomach is identified based on the fluid presence (hypodense region).
  • Rightside to the stomach is the liver, which extends upto the anterior abdominal wall.
  • Leftside to the stomach, the spleen in located more in the posterior position
  • The pancreas is located immediately posterior to the stomach in the given image.

 

Anatomy of the abdomen in the coronal (left) and axial plane (right)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with severe abdominal pain following alcohol intake. Make a diagnosis based on the given X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pneumoperitoneum

Explanation:

  • The X-ray given above shows the presence of air under the diaphragm without any visible bowel markings, which is indicative of pneumoperitoneum.

 

Pneumoperitoneum

  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of free gas in the peritoneal cavity, typically indicating a perforated viscus (e.g., perforated peptic ulcer).
  • Causes:
    • Common: Perforated peptic ulcers, bowel obstruction, inflammatory conditions, ischemia, injury during colonoscopy.
    • Other causes without peritonitis: Postoperative (up to 7 days), peritoneal dialysis, sealed perforation, and tracking from pneumomediastinum.
  • Diagnosis on Imaging:
    • Erect CXR: Free gas seen under the right hemidiaphragm (cupola sign), difficult to differentiate on the left due to gastric or colonic gas.
    • Supine AXR: Right upper quadrant gas in the perihepatic, subhepatic space, Morrison’s pouch, and ligament visualization (e.g., falciform ligament).
    • Rigler’s Sign: Visualization of both sides of the bowel wall due to surrounding gas.
    • CT Scan: Most sensitive; small volumes of gas seen in the liver or peritoneal recesses, often using broad window settings.
  • Pseudo-pneumoperitoneum: Conditions mimicking free gas such as Chilaiditi syndrome (intestine between liver and diaphragm), subphrenic abscess, or subdiaphragmatic fat.
  • Pneumoperitoneum may be clinically silent, especially in elderly, steroid-treated, unconscious, or critically ill patients.

 

Small bowel obstruction (SBO) (Option B): typically presents with dilated bowel loops, air-fluid levels, and no free air under the diaphragm.

Esophageal perforation (Option C): While it can lead to air escaping into surrounding areas, it more commonly results in pneumomediastinum or subcutaneous emphysema rather than free air under the diaphragm.

Pneumomediastinum (Option D): Air in the mediastinum is seen along the heart border and mediastinal structures, not under the diaphragm.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Jejunal atresia

Explanation:

  • Jejunal atresia is characterized by a triple bubble sign, as shown in the X-ray. It also shows an apple peel appearance.

 

Various Bubble signs of the abdomen:

Condition

Radiological Sign

Explanation

Normal Abdomen

Single bubble in the stomach

A single air bubble seen in the left upper quadrant corresponds to the fundus of the stomach. A large single bubble is seen in cases of pyloric atresia, GOO.

Pyloric Atresia (Option A)

"Single bubble" sign

A single distended stomach with no air in the small bowel or beyond, caused by obstruction at the pylorus.

 

Duodenal Atresia

(Option A)

"Double bubble" sign

Distended stomach and proximal duodenum; no distal bowel gas due to obstruction at the duodenum.

Jejunal Atresia

 

"Triple bubble" sign

Three distended loops of bowel (stomach, duodenum, proximal jejunum) with no distal gas.

Ileal Atresia

(Option D)

Multiple air-fluid levels

Dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels and no gas in the large intestine, more distal than jejunal atresia.

 

Small bowel obstruction (Option C): A step ladder pattern is seen in small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A newborn presents with bilious vomiting. Which sign is depicted in the following radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Double bubble sign:

  • The double bubble sign is a radiological finding seen on an abdominal X-ray or ultrasound in cases of duodenal atresia or stenosis.
  • It is characterized by the presence of two distinct air-filled bubbles in the abdomen: one representing the stomach and the other representing the dilated portion of the proximal duodenum.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Air crescent sign:

  • The air crescent sign is typically seen in radiological imaging of patients with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.
  • It appears as a crescent-shaped pocket of air surrounding a lung nodule or cavity.

Option C - Cupola sign:

  • The cupola sign is seen on a supine chest or abdominal radiograph in the presence of pneumoperitoneum.
  • It refers to non-dependent gas that rises within the abdominal cavity of the supine patient to accumulate underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline.

Option D - Triple bubble sign:

  • The triple bubble sign is the classic radiographic appearance observed in jejunal atresia.
  • The appearance is due to a proximal obstruction caused by the atretic jejunum.

questions.text: Please identify the section of the intestine shown in the barium study provided.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Jejunum

Explanation:

The jejunum is the second part of the small intestine, following the duodenum and preceding the ileum. It is typically characterized by:

  • A thicker, more vascular wall compared to the ileum.
  • Plicae circulares (circular folds) are prominent in the jejunum, and the mucosal surface appears folded in the barium study.
  • The barium study would show coarse, dense mucosal folds which is a distinctive feature of the jejunum.

Various Bubble signs of the abdomen:

Condition

Radiological Sign

Explanation

Normal Abdomen

Single bubble in the stomach

A single air bubble seen in the left upper quadrant corresponds to the fundus of the stomach. A large single bubble is seen in cases of pyloric atresia, GOO.

Pyloric Atresia

"Single bubble" sign

A single distended stomach with no air in the small bowel or beyond, caused by obstruction at the pylorus.

 

Duodenal Atresia

"Double bubble" sign

Distended stomach and proximal duodenum; no distal bowel gas due to obstruction at the duodenum.

Jejunal Atresia

"Triple bubble" sign

Three distended loops of bowel (stomach, duodenum, proximal jejunum) with no distal gas.

Ileal Atresia

Multiple air-fluid levels

Dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels and no gas in the large intestine, more distal than jejunal atresia.

 

Ileum (option A): Incorrect because the ileum is the third and longest part of the small intestine. It is often characterized by fewer, less prominent folds compared to the jejunum and a thinner wall. In a barium study, it would show less dense mucosal folds than the jejunum.

Transverse colon (option B): Incorrect because the transverse colon is part of the large intestine, which would appear with a wider lumen and less defined folds compared to the small intestine. The characteristic features of the transverse colon would not match the dense folds of the jejunum seen in the barium study.

Splenic flexure (option D): Incorrect because the splenic flexure is the bend between the ascending colon and the descending colon, located near the spleen. It has a much larger and less folded appearance compared to the jejunum in a barium study.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with chills and rigors. She has acute pain in the right flank region. The imaging is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Emphysematous pyelonephritis

Explanation:

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis:

  • This is a severe, necrotizing infection of the kidney, typically caused by gas-producing organisms (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella).
  • The hallmark imaging feature in CT scan would be the presence of gas in the renal parenchyma or renal collecting system.
  • Symptoms typically include flank pain, fever, chills, and rigors, and it is commonly seen in diabetic patients or those with immunocompromised states.
  • The radiological finding of gas within the renal parenchyma on the CT scan supports this diagnosis.

Acute Pyelonephritis

Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis

Ultrasound (USG): This may show kidney enlargement, reduced echogenicity, and dilated collecting systems.

 

 

 

Ultrasound (USG): Shows an enlarged kidney with echogenic staghorn calculi and hypoechoic masses replacing renal parenchyma.

 

 

Plain Abdominal X-ray: Detects gas in the kidney region in about 70% of cases.

 

 

Contrast-enhanced CT: Most sensitive, showing wedge-shaped hypodense areas, striated nephrograms, and pelvic wall thickening.

 

CT Scan reveals a non-functioning kidney, staghorn calculus, expanded calyces, and inflammatory changes. A characteristic bear paw sign is noted.

 

CT: Gold standard, reveals gas within the kidney, renal enlargement, perinephric stranding and abscesses. Helps classify into Type 1 (gas without fluid) or Type 2 (gas with fluid).

 

Acute infection of the kidney involving the renal parenchyma and collecting system is usually caused by ascending bacteria.
  • It is a chronic granulomatous response to recurrent renal infection - that leads to the destruction of renal parenchyma and its replacement by lipid-laden foamy macrophages.
  • Destruction spreads from the renal pelvis→medulla→ cortex.
  • Usually, staghorn calculus is present in the pelvis.

Severe necrotizing infection with gas accumulation in and around the kidney, primarily in diabetic patients.

 

Cholecystitis (option A): Incorrect because cholecystitis is an inflammation of the gallbladder, typically presenting with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The imaging would show gallstones and a thickened gallbladder wall rather than gas in the renal system.

Small bowel obstruction (option C): Incorrect because small bowel obstruction presents with symptoms of vomiting, abdominal distension, and failure to pass flatus or stool. Imaging would typically show dilated loops of bowel and air-fluid levels, not gas in the kidney or renal system.

Volvulus (option D): Incorrect because volvulus refers to the twisting of the bowel, leading to bowel obstruction. It would cause abdominal distension, pain, and vomiting, with imaging showing distended loops of bowel and sometimes a twisted mesenteric root. There would be no gas in the kidney or renal parenchyma.

questions.text: What could be the most probable diagnosis for an elderly woman who is experiencing abdominal pain and swelling, considering her past medical history of scoliosis? Please refer to the provided X-ray image of the woman's upright abdomen for further information.

choices.text: Large bowel obstruction due to sigmoid volvulus
Large bowel obstruction due to faecolith
Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.solution:
The Omega sign, coffee bean sign, or bent tube sign on a plain abdominal X-ray is classic for sigmoid volvulus. It results from twisting of the sigmoid colon, leading to a large, dilated, U-shaped loop with an apex pointing toward the diaphragm.

 

Sigmoid volvulus is common in elderly patients, especially those with a history of chronic constipation or conditions like scoliosis, which may cause colonic redundancy or altered anatomy.

 

Sigmoid Volvulus

Caecal Volvulus
  • Sigmoid volvulus arises in the pelvis, specifically the left lower quadrant.
  • It extends towards the right upper quadrant.
  • It has an ahaustral appearance (lack of haustra).
  • Causes obstruction of the distal large bowel, leading to dilation of the ascending, transverse, and descending colon.
  • A few gas-fluid levels may be seen.
  • Coffee-Bean Sign: The condition is characterized by a distended sigmoid loop with an inverted U shape, known as the coffee-bean sign (or kidney bean sign).
  • Whirlpool Sign: The whirl, or whirlpool sign is observed when the bowel rotates around its mesentery, resulting in whirls of the mesenteric vessels.
  • The torsion is located in the ascending colon above the ileocecal valve.
  • Caecal volvulus arises in the right lower quadrant.
  • It extends towards the epigastrium or left upper quadrant.
  • The colonic haustral pattern is maintained.
  • The distal colon is usually collapsed, and the small bowel is distended.
  • One gas-fluid level may be seen.
  • Definitive Sign: Upward displacement of the appendix and obstruction of the large bowel is a definitive sign of cecal volvulus.
  • May show a U-shaped distended bowel segment and signs of ischemia, including mural thickening, infiltration of the mesenteric fat, and pneumatosis intestinalis.
  • Whirlpool Sign: A whirl sign may be apparent due to tight torsion of the mesentery from a twist between the afferent and efferent loops.
  • Coffee Bean Appearance: A "coffee bean" appearance may be seen in a loop of transverse colon.
  • Bird's Beak Sign: Abrupt cut-off with “bird's beak” tapering at the distal cecum is characteristic.
  • Central appendix sign: Abnormal appendix position near midline.

Large bowel obstruction due to faecolith (Option B): This is incorrect because faecoliths are typically seen as radio-opaque masses in the colon and do not produce the characteristic "coffee bean sign."

 

Cecal volvulus (Option C): This is incorrect because cecal volvulus shows a dilated cecum displaced to the midline or left upper quadrant, not the classic U-shaped appearance of sigmoid volvulus.

 

Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation (Option D): This is incorrect because small bowel obstruction typically shows multiple air-fluid levels and dilated loops of the small intestine. A perforation would present with free air under the diaphragm on an upright X-ray, not a coffee bean sign.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Football sign
			
			
			a. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
			
		
		
			
			2. String sign
			
			
			b. Achalasia cardia
			
		
		
			
			3. Rat tail sign
			
			
			c. Ileocecal TB
			
		
		
			
			4. Inverted umbrella sign
			
			
			d. Pneumoperitoneum
questions.solution:
Football sign (d): Pneumoperitoneum

  • Seen on abdominal X-rays, the football sign indicates free intraperitoneal air outlining the peritoneal cavity, creating the appearance of an "American football."

String sign (a): Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

  • Refers to a thin, elongated pyloric canal seen on upper GI contrast studies, characteristic of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Rat tail sign (b): Achalasia cardia

  • A tapering of the distal oesophagus with smooth narrowing on barium swallow, resembling a rat tail, is indicative of achalasia.

Inverted umbrella sign (c): Ileocecal tuberculosis

  • A deformity of the ileocecal region with contracted cecum and pulled-up ileum, resembling an inverted umbrella, is typical of ileocecal TB.

questions.text: Which of the following images accurately represents the medical condition described in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia:

  • The image and the clinical features suggest a diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) occurs when the diaphragm, the muscle that separates the chest from the abdomen, fails to close during prenatal development.
  • It can be due to a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane that results in compression of the lungs by the intestine.

Incorrect options

Option B: Intestinal obstruction

  • Intestinal obstruction does not result in displacement of heart sounds and diminished breathing sounds.

Option C: Pleural effusion

  • Pleural effusion results in dullness on percussion and also blunting of costophrenic angles.
  • There is no displacement of heart sounds.

Option D: Pneumonia

  • Pneumonia in neonates is fairly common. However, there is no displacement of the bowel hence no displacement of heart sounds.

questions.text: All of the following could be the cause of the presence of free air under the diaphragm except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Acute intestinal obstruction refers to a blockage in the intestine that prevents the passage of intestinal contents. While acute intestinal obstruction can cause distension of the bowel and the accumulation of gas and fluid, it typically does not result in free air under the diaphragm. The presence of free air under the diaphragm is more suggestive of perforation or leakage of air from a hollow organ into the peritoneal cavity. 

 

Incorrect options

Option A: Duodenal ulcer perforation refers to a complication of a duodenal ulcer in which a hole forms in the wall of the duodenum. This can result in the leakage of gastrointestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to a condition called pneumoperitoneum. Pneumoperitoneum can be visualized on an X-ray as free air under the diaphragm, indicating the presence of air in the abdominal cavity.

Option B: Post laparoscopy refers to the period following a laparoscopic surgery. During laparoscopy, carbon dioxide gas is used to inflate the abdominal cavity, creating space for the surgeon to operate. After the surgery, some residual carbon dioxide gas may remain in the abdomen. This residual gas can be visualized on an X-ray as small pockets of air or gas bubbles.

Option C: Chilaiditi syndrome is a rare condition characterized by the interposition of the colon between the liver and the diaphragm. This can lead to the trapping of gas in the colonic segments under the liver, resulting in the appearance of gas-filled spaces on an X-ray. Therefore, Chilaiditi syndrome can be a cause of the X-ray finding.

questions.text: In which of the following medical conditions can the X-ray finding be observed?
questions.solution:
Correction Option C: Reflux esophagitis

  • Reflux esophagitis is the condition for which X-ray findings may show signs of esophageal inflammation, such as mucosal irregularities, ulcerations, or strictures.
  • Reflux esophagitis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the esophagus due to the backward flow of stomach acid and contents. I
  • It is typically associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Incorrect options

Option A: Esophageal atresia- Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition in which the esophagus does not properly connect to the stomach. X-ray findings for esophageal atresia may show an absence or air-filled pouch in the upper or lower part of the esophagus. This abnormality can be detected on an X-ray examination with contrast material.

Option B: Esophageal stenosis- Esophageal stenosis refers to a narrowing or constriction of the esophagus. It can be caused by various factors, including scarring, inflammation, or abnormal tissue growth. X-ray findings for esophageal stenosis may show a narrowing or "pinched" appearance of the esophagus on a contrast-enhanced X-ray study.

Option D: Barrett's esophagus- Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the normal lining of the esophagus is replaced with abnormal cells resembling those found in the intestine. This change is often associated with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus typically requires an endoscopic examination with biopsy. X-ray findings alone may not be indicative of Barrett's esophagus

questions.text: Identify the sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Target sign

  • Abdominal ultrasound. Target sign of an ileocecal intussusception in the right lower quadrant (arrows). The classic ultrasound image of intussusception is a ‘bull's eye', ‘coiled spring' or ‘target sign' lesion (intraluminal mass or intussusceptum) representing layers of the intestine within the intestine.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Claw sign : Also seen in intussusception

Option C: Coffee bean sign : The presence of the coffee bean sign is pathognomonic of sigmoid volvulus. 

Option D: Lead pipe sign : Seen in ulcerative colitis

questions.text: Investigation of choice for GERD:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • GERD is a chronic condition characterized by the reflux of stomach acid into the esophagus, leading to symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation, and chest discomfort. The goal of investigations for GERD is to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of acid reflux.
  • 24-hour pH monitoring is considered the gold standard investigation for GERD. It involves placing a pH probe into the esophagus to measure and record the pH levels for a 24-hour period. This allows for the detection of abnormal acid exposure in the esophagus, helping to establish the diagnosis of GERD and assess its severity.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: USG (Ultrasound): USG is not typically used as an investigation for GERD. It is more commonly employed for evaluating abdominal organs, such as the liver, gallbladder, or kidneys, and may be useful in assessing other conditions that can mimic GERD, such as gallbladder disease or pancreatitis.

Option B : HIDA (Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid) scan: HIDA scan is not indicated as an investigation for GERD. It is primarily used for evaluating the biliary system, such as in cases of suspected gallbladder dysfunction or biliary obstruction.

Option C: Manometry: Esophageal manometry measures the pressure and motility of the esophagus and is used to assess esophageal function. While manometry may be helpful in evaluating other esophageal conditions, such as achalasia or esophageal motility disorders, it is not the investigation of choice for GERD.

questions.text: A 40 yr old man comes with a history of retrosternal chest pain and dysphagia, Barium meal was done given below. What is the classical pattern of dysphagia found in this condition?

choices.text: Progressive dysphagia more for solids >> liquids

questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

Option A: More for liquids >> solids: This pattern is consistent with achalasia. In achalasia, dysphagia is more associated with liquids.

Incorrect Option:

Option B: Progressive Dysphagia for liquids = solids : This is incorrect

Option C: Progressive dysphagia more for solids >> liquids: This pattern does not align with the classical presentation of achalasia.

Option D: Intermittent dysphagia for solids = liquids: This pattern is not characteristic of achalasia.

questions.text: What would be your subsequent step when encountering a child who has a documented case of ingesting a button battery?

choices.text: Reassure and check whether passed in stools

questions.solution:
Correct Option B 

  • In the case of a child who has ingested a button battery, the next course of action would typically be to remove the battery endoscopically. 
  • Button batteries are small, round batteries commonly found in devices such as remote controls, toys, and watches. Ingestion of a button battery is considered a medical emergency due to the potential risks and complications it can cause. These batteries can cause significant damage to the esophagus and other nearby structures if they get stuck or become lodged.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A. Giving oral fluids: While maintaining hydration is important, giving oral fluids is not the appropriate next step when a child has ingested a button battery. Prompt removal of the battery is necessary to minimize the risk of complications.

Option C. Reassure and check whether passed in stools: Ingested button batteries should not be assumed to pass through the digestive system without complications. Button batteries can cause serious harm if they get lodged or cause damage to the gastrointestinal tract. Therefore, reassurance and waiting for the battery to pass in stools are not appropriate actions.

Option D. Inducing vomiting: Inducing vomiting is not recommended in cases of button battery ingestion. The battery can cause damage while being regurgitated, and it is important to avoid further injury to the esophagus or surrounding tissues.
